docs.lead_paragraph: ''Things fall apart,'' bemoaned the poet Yeats, ''the center cannot hold. . . .'' Not so today. In three critical areas, the center is holding up fine.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column expresses satisfaction with three recent events in Washington: Pres Bush's decision to withdraw US from 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty over objections of Pres Vladimir Putin of Russia; compromises made by left and right to arrive at anti-recession measure; and government's decision to file first indictment stemming from Sept 11 terrorist attacks in federal courts rather than military tribunal (M)
docs.snippet: ''Things fall apart,'' bemoaned the poet Yeats, ''the center cannot hold. . . .''    Not so today. In three critical areas, the center is holding up fine.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Parity for Mental Health'' (editorial, Dec. 10): Our political leaders can acknowledge the impact of trauma and its depressive and overwhelming effect on all of us since Sept. 11. Have we resolved that trauma in 10 sessions, as insurance companies often demand? The psychology, even amid biological factors, of depression and other mental disorders always involves the working through of childhood traumatic events, or chronic helplessness from unresponsive caretaking environments.

headline.main: To Douse the Fire in the Mind

docs.abstract: Letter from Mark D Smaller suports Dec 10 editorial's call for health insurance parity for mental health (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of heavy losses, the St. Paul Companies will exit the medical malpractice insurance business, ending coverage for 750 hospitals, 42,000 physicians and 73,000 other health care workers nationwide, the company said yesterday. St. Paul said its losses had mounted despite average increases of 24 percent in its malpractice rates in more than 25 states, some of the highest increases since the mid-1980's. Fueled by resentments against managed care, jury awards against doctors and hospitals now average $3.49 million each, according to Jury Verdict Research of Horsham, Pa.

headline.main: St. Paul Cos. Exits Medical Malpractice Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Mind and Body,'' by Mike Wallace (Op-Ed, Dec. 11): I propose asking all those House leaders opposing the bill eliminating health coverage disparity for physical and mental illnesses to explain and justify their outrageous position. Under the full glare of this nation, perhaps these members might open their minds and perhaps lower this new height of their arrogance.

docs.lead_paragraph: American Express to Cut Up to 6,500 More Jobs American Express, which has laid off 7,700 employees this year, plans to eliminate an additional 5,500 to 6,500 jobs. A spokesman said that more than half of the job cuts would be in the company's travel business, which has slumped sharply since the Sept. 11 attacks. The remainder will be spread through the rest of the company. [Page C4.] Yahoo Makes Bid for HotJobs.Com Trying to bolster its online recruiting business, Yahoo made an unsolicited bid to buy HotJobs.com, the Internet's second-largest career site, for $436 million in cash and stock. [C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses for Sickest Workers'' (front page, Dec. 5) points out the downside of a new approach to corporate expense reduction. The employers' share of a new health care product would decrease, as would the average premium, but the burden would be shifted to sick people! This is unwise public policy. When seriously ill, most patients are not working, and their families are burdened by additional expense already. And if the major costs of modern medicine are shifted directly to patients, they are more likely to defer diagnostic procedures and filling prescriptions, and therefore get sicker. Sooner or later, we will all get the bill.
docs.abstract: Dr Steven Wolfson letter on Dec 5 article opposes corporate health insurance that shifts more of costs to patientsm

docs.lead_paragraph: THE relation between family circumstances and a child's academic proficiency is well known, but policymakers usually assume that if all children can be held to the same standards, the achievement gap between rich and poor will eventually disappear. We pay too little attention to how social and economic forces themselves influence learning. Unemployment has now risen to 5.7 percent, up from less than 4 percent in October 2000. The biggest downturns have been in low-wage industries like hotels and restaurants. More job losses are expected.

headline.main: An Economic Recovery Will Tell in the Classroom

docs.abstract: Richard Rothstein comments on relation between family economic circumstances and child's academic proficiency, and how social and economic forces themselves influence learning; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With unemployment rising and the outlook for recovery muddled, the Federal Reserve continued its campaign of interest rate cuts today as President Bush and the two parties in Congress made progress in reviving negotiations on an economic stimulus package. The Fed reduced its main lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 1.75 percent, the 11th time this year it has cut borrowing costs. In announcing the move, the Fed, the nation's central bank, noted signs that the downturn may be reaching a bottom, the first time the Fed has done so since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. But it added that the positive signs were tentative, and it left the door open to further rate cuts in the new year.

headline.main: With the Economy Still Fragile, the Fed Again Cuts Rates

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve reduces target for federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 1.75 percent, eleventh cut in borrowing costs in 2001; Congress and Pres Bush hasten to revive negotiations on economic stimulus package and pledge willingness to compromise; burden for lifting economy remains on Federal Reserve because there is no assurance that Congress and administration will enact stimulus bill (M)
docs.snippet: With unemployment rising and the outlook for recovery muddled, the Federal Reserve continued its campaign of interest rate cuts today as President Bush and the two parties in Congress made progress in reviving negotiations on an economic stimulus...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Pritzkers, one of the nation's wealthiest families and heirs to the fortune created by the Hyatt hotels, agreed today to pay a record $460 million to the federal government to avoid being punished for the failure of Superior Bank F.S.B., the big savings and loan institution that regulators seized last summer. Federal officials said the payment, which will be spread out over 15 years, is the largest settlement ever in the failure of a banking institution. The failure itself is one of the largest in the last decade, one that some estimate could cost the government up to $1 billion.

headline.main: Hyatt Hotel Family Will Pay $460 Million in S.& L. Case

docs.abstract: Pritzkers, one of nation's wealthiest families and heirs to Hyatt hotels fortune, agrees to pay record $460 million to federal government to avoid other punishment for failure of Superior Bank FSB, which regulators attribute to poor lending practices and sloppy bookkeeping; settlement represents minor victory for Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Office of Thrift Supervision; regulators investigate audit by Ernst & Young that showed bank to be in good financial condition shortly before its collapse (M)
docs.snippet: The Pritzkers, one of the nation's wealthiest families and heirs to the fortune created by the Hyatt hotels, agreed today to pay a record $460 million to the federal government to avoid being punished for the failure of Superior Bank F.S.B., the big...

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to keep their long downward slide from becoming a death spiral, the nation's old-line steel makers are pressing the federal government for special treatment granted to almost no other industry. They are almost certainly overreaching, analysts say. And even if the industry succeeds in getting what it wants, the plan would do little more, critics say, than put off the day when it succumbs to subsidized foreign rivals and a nimble new breed of domestic competitors that oppose granting big steel makers the concessions they are seeking.

headline.main: Big Steel: An Invalid That Can Roar In Washington

docs.abstract: Richard W Stevenson analysis special treatment from government sought by big steel companies; companies seek protection from low-priced imports, federal money to help pay health and pension benefits and assurance that mergers of steel companies into giant competitor will not run into antitrust problems, and they want US to pressure other nations to scale back their steel-making capacities; analysts say that companies are overreaching and that even if industry succeeds in getting what it wants, plan would do little more than put off day when it succumbs to subsidized foreign rival and nimble new breed of domestic competitors that oppose concessions sought by Big Steel; Bush administration is opening to some parts of plan, but is wary of embracing others; photo (M)
